snippet.title: Snowden: Dear Brazil, the NSA is watching you
snippet.description: In a letter to the people of Brazil, Edward Snowden offers to help uncover NSA surveillance on Brazilian citizens in exchange for permanent asylum.

snippet.title: Text messages licking stamps in Scandinavia
snippet.description: Denmark is launching SMS stamps next month, with Sweden to follow. Germany has a similar system, but the text-message codes cost more than normal stamps.

snippet.title: Text messages replacing stamps for Scandinavian posties
snippet.description: Scandinavian posties are using mobile phones to lick the problem of buying stamps, with postage paid via text message.

snippet.title: Eye-catching HP notebook
snippet.description: Hewlett-Packard's user-submitted design winner, a Portuguese design student, makes it to CES. "Asian Odyssey" design is splashed atop 14-inch 2000 series notebook.

snippet.title: Gadget lifestyles: iPod dock is into leather
snippet.description: We hope this trend won't be overdone

snippet.title: Mini-subs exploring Sacramento River
snippet.description: UC Berkeley researchers are developing new devices to better understand how water flows from California's mountains into drinking water supplies.

snippet.title: Brazil: A chip in every cow
snippet.description: The giant South American nation is trying to use its large cattle population to create a market for a homegrown semiconductor industry.

snippet.title: A radiation detector for inside the body
snippet.description: It was made for spacecraft, but the radiation detector can be used in cancer patients, too.

snippet.title: XO laptop: Better to give, receive or both?
snippet.description: The Get 1, Give 1 promotion for the $100 laptop is very tempting.

snippet.title: Playing the open-source samba
snippet.description: John Perry Barlow tells the World Social Forum that "Brazil spends more in licensing fees on proprietary software than it spends on hunger."
